review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
Idol Hands, oyuncuların kendi halklarını yönlendirerek dünyayı ele geçirdiği bir strateji oyunudur. Oyuncular, tanrı olarak halklarının davranışları üzerinde doğrudan kontrol sahibi değildir, ancak halkları binalar inşa ederek, ürün yetiştirerek ve kendilerini mikro yöneterek hayatlarını sürdürürler. Oyuncuların güçleri kullanılarak, halklarına kullanılabilir toprak sağlayabilir, onları saldırılardan koruyabilir ve doğayı kontrol edebilirler. Oyuncuların yardımıyla halkları büyüyüp gelişebilir, hasatlarının bolluğunu artırabilir ve sonunda kendi halklarına karşı kullanabilecekleri devasa bir askeri güç oluşturarak rakiplerini yok edebilirler.

Oyunun ana özellikleri arasında, oyuncuların bir ulus takipçisiyle Tanrı gibi oynama imkanı, tamamen 3D bir dünya oluşturma, doğal afetlerin tetiklenmesiyle düşmanlarını yok etme gücü ve oyuncuların kendi oyun stratejilerini belirleyebilme özgürlüğü yer alıyor. Her oyunun benzersiz olması için birden fazla strateji mevcuttur. Ancak, oyuncuların oyunun bazı teknik sorunları nedeniyle karışık incelemelerde yer aldığını belirtmek gerekir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198796851430', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 3717, 'playtime_forever': 7309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1677126745}
review:
首先，这游戏的核心玩法听着挺新鲜，让玩家扮演一位神明指导子民征服其他世界，不过实际操作起来，那叫一个捉急。神明对人间事务的干预手段实在是有限得紧，有时候你觉得自己像个摆设，看着你的信徒们傻乎乎地自行其是，你只能干瞪眼，这哪是“引导”，简直是“望洋兴叹”。

再者，游戏中的AI逻辑也让人挠头。你那群信徒的行为模式有时毫无章法，经常做出些让你哭笑不得的决定，而你要么无力改变，要么就得花费大量的资源才能稍微调整一下他们的行动路线，整个过程既缺乏深度又显得颇为被动。

画面上虽然采用了卡通风格，但视觉效果并不出众，界面设计略显混乱，一不小心就会错过重要信息。音效配乐也是平淡无奇，很难让人沉浸在那个充满神话色彩的世界中。

说到游戏教程和引导系统，更是让人头疼的地方。对于新手玩家来说，学习曲线过于陡峭，游戏机制介绍不够清晰，往往会让初次接触的玩家感到无所适从，不知道从何下手去发挥神力。

此外，游戏的重复性较高，随着游戏进程深入，你会发现大部分的任务和挑战都大同小异，缺乏足够的多样性来保持玩家的兴趣。而且，后期升级和发展系统的复杂程度与其乐趣不成正比，让人有种疲于奔命的感觉。

总结来说虽然创意不错，但在执行层面出现了不少问题，从玩家互动体验到游戏内容丰富度都有待改进。作为一款模拟策略游戏，它未能充分利用其独特的设定来打造引人入胜的玩法，导致整体游戏体验较为平淡且令人失望。如果你想在这款游戏中体验做神的快感，恐怕你会发现自己更多的时候是在祈祷游戏能变得更有趣一些。

review:
This could have been a cheap simple casual god game, but it's far too flawed to recommend even at $5.

The god-game aspects are minimal. It has very basic resource gathering to service a lackluster RTS gimmick that doesn't provide much challenge. Now as a casual strategy game that might have been OK, if the game actually worked well, but it doesn't.

You'll encounter a lot of glitches, the frame rates will lag even on a system that far exceeds requirements, and just to be annoying it likes to crash frequently.

On top of that the controls aren't great, the story is poorly written, there's very little variation from one level to the next and if it didn't crash so much you can probably finish the entire thing in about 2 hours or less; making it barely worth the effort or the price even if it ran well, which it doesn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1618329460}
review:
"Idol Hands" ist ein kleines God-Game im Populous-Stil.

Wie das Spiel wirklich in seiner Gänze ist, kann ich leider nicht beurteilen, denn es lagt und stottert bis zur Unspielbarkeit. Und dieses Problem haben anscheinend Viele und es scheint auch nicht lösbar zu sein. Eine Änderung der Grafikeinstellung ändert auch nichts an dem Problem. Das Ganze scheint wahrscheinlich eine Art Inkompatibilität mit Windows 10 zu sein. Das Spiel so zu spielen ist nahezu unmöglich, da es ständig für mehrere Sekunden einfriert. Ironischerweise nennt sich das Entwicklerstudio Fluid Games.

Ich habe dennoch versucht, die grundlegenden Mechaniken auszuprobieren und ansonsten Gameplay-Videos studiert.

Und danach muß ich leider sagen, daß das Spiel, auch wenn es normal laufen würde, nicht gerade überzeugen würde.

Auf einer begrenzten Karte gibt es zwei Völker. Wir sind der Gott des einen und müssen über die Zeit den Gegner niederringen. Dafür müssen wir erstmal unser Volk wachsen lassen. Am wichtigsten hierfür ist es, das Terrain zu ebnen, um unserem Volk neue und größere Bauplätze zu ermöglichen. Dann können wir den einzelnen Wesen Berufe zuordnen und sie zum Beispiel als Holzfäller, Farmer oder Schmied arbeiten lassen. Die Häuser der Wesen werden dabei automatisch von den Wesen gebaut. Wir können auch Krieger zuweisen, die dann den Gegner angreifen können.

Mit Mana, das wir über die Anbetung unserer Wesen stetig bekommen, können wir nicht nur Terrain ebnen, sondern es auch regnen lassen oder unserem Gegner mit Erdbeben oder Blitzen zusetzen. 

Das klingt alles recht nett, ist aber dann doch sehr schnell sehr begrenzt. Es gibt nur wenige Berufe und die Anzahl der in ihnen zugewiesenen Wesen ist auch begrenzt. Dadurch spielt sich jede Partie, jedes Level praktisch gleich. Unsere Eingriffsmöglichkeiten als Gott sind auch oft limitiert. Wir können viel terraformen, da das wenig Mana braucht, alles andere ist aber durch die hohen Manakosten nur selten verwendbar. 

Der Stil soll irgendwie süß sein, ist aber nicht konsistent. Die Wesen sprechen in einem extrem nervigen und unsympathischen Mickey Mouse-Ton mit Einem, der klar macht, daß die Entwickler offenbar nicht wirklich das Budget für ernstzunehmende Sprecher hatten. Auch ansonsten bewegen wir uns auf simpelstem Tablet-Niveau. Grafisch ist das Game ziemlich häßlich und unbeholfen.

Also kurz und gut: das Spiel funktioniert nicht, aber selbst wenn es funktionierte, würde es keine Empfehlung bekommen.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
5/10 Atmosphäre
4/10 Story
5/10 Grafik
4/10 Sound
5/10 Spielmechanik
3/10 Balancing
3/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Freeze of God by Fluid Games.

[h1][b]-/10 Gesamtwertung (keine Wertung, da durch Einfrieren unspielbar.)

review:
一款创世神视角的沙盒游戏
操控上并不用技能非常细致的控制每个单位的移动、工作等事情
而是类似于发出神迹，比如初期的改变地形（按键z下沉地面，按键z使得四周地形平整，按键c抬高地形），以及中后期获得的下雨、雷击、地震、流星、火山爆发技能
每个技能都有自己的魔法消耗，魔法恢复速度好像和人口数量有关，类似于祈祷值
除此之外你还可以再自己的祭坛里选择子民的职业方向（shift切换到祭坛界面），总共5个职业，各有各的不同消耗与作用：
伐木工，砍树，获取木头资源；农民，种地，增加食物/人口上限；铁匠，挖矿，获取铁资源；牧师，祈祷，增加魔法恢复速度；士兵，出征、防御

一些小技巧：
建筑物是需要从祭坛逐渐向外扩张的，而且只能建造在平地上，需要用改变地形的能力逐渐改造；但要注意如果你改变的地形上面有己方的建筑，并且地形改变幅度很大的话可能直接摧毁了这些建筑，甚至使得里面的居民直接死亡
另外有些森林地区如果用改变地形能力的话也会导致树木全部倒塌，自己的伐木工就无法砍伐树木获得资源了，只能向更远的地区移动
下雨技能无法主动攻击，但可以在己方着火（被对方攻击）的建筑上面释放从而降低持续伤害，不过基本上没啥用，还不如直接留着魔法来攻击
场景里冒着闪光的矿藏是无法采取的，需要用改变地形能力来使之暴露在外面（就是在上面先抬高或降低，然后再平整就行了，如果没效果就多试几次）

游戏玩法上其实是挺吸引人的，但整个游戏的问题很多
最重要的是优化极差，你会发现游戏内存用的不算多、CPU也不高、显卡也不吃，但TMD就是掉帧，而且是非常严重的掉帧，整个游戏体验完全被破坏掉了
另外，消灭敌人太困难了，和己方一样，没有职业的平民（人口）会不停刷新，只要有人口就能变成伐木工，有了伐木工就能砍木头，有了木头又能招农民
生生不息，好不容易你把一个角落的建筑物给摧毁了，然后再另一边里又滋生出了一大堆敌人的建筑，然后只能反反复复的消耗对方的资源，直到对方什么造不出了你的士兵才肯去把他们的祭坛给消灭掉

review:
I'm not sure why this game has such mixed reviews. I found this game a clever little gem for under $5. For the price its amazing! I'm over an hour in and I'm still having fun just playing the tutorial quests. Haven't even switched to the main game yet I'm having so much fun. Its super cute. Has different camera angles and CAN zoon unlike some of the other reviews had said. You mine resources to get the guys you need to conquer the world. Simple, casual, and fun to play.
I got it as I LOVED populous back in the day and this seemed similar. I say watch the videos and forget the reviews and try it for yourself. I give so many games with mixed and bad reviews a chance and glad I did this one as well. :D

**Quick update. I finished the game and I had a lot of fun. So for $5 I got my 5 hours of play time out if it that I would have liked. One of the few games that held my attention till the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128438397', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1474, 'last_played': 1521377105}
review:
Very beatiful game with it`s own atmosphere, but not without minuses tho.
+ God Simulator in Populous-3-style more then Black&White
+ Nice graphics: very simple, PC with medium configuration will play it on high level
+ Easy to learn, simple mechanics

Now about minuses:
- Bugs with Save/Load. You can`t load saved game at all, but you can start last level anew. 
- Stupid AI, you can win using simple strategies. One level of difficulty.
- Short compaign, which is ended with eternal sandbox level without opponents: you just build a town.
- There`s now help tips or some mission targets. You will play by your own. It`s bad if read it with previous point.

review:
Un petit jeu grandement inspiré & qui rappellera le GodGame culte "Black & White" sortie en 2001...
Mais, c'est en gros une version embryonaire casual de ce même jeu... (pas de créature ni de gestion de bien ou de mal, pas de quêtes etc...)
On ne pourra créer que 5 types de villageois (bucheron, paysan, forgeron, soldat & prêtre) ce qui créera les 3 ressources automatiquement (nourriture, bois & minerai), les soldats seront utilisé pour l'attaque, les prêtres en défense pour convertir les assayants.
Il nous faudra uniquement applanir le terrain pour que les champs/batiments se construisent tout seuls en fonction du nombre d'unités choisies & pour atteindre les minerais... sinon aucune possibilité de gérer la disposition du village, ni aucune séléction d'unités possible après coup.
On pourra de même creuser ou monter le terrain pour atteindre des ressources ou ralentir l'adversaire ou carrement utiliser un des 5 pouvoirs qui se débloquent au fur & à mesure (pluie, éclairs, tremblement de terre, boule de feu & volcan), le tout gérer par la mana gagnée en fonction du nombre d'habitants.
Malheureusement on ne pourra pas indiquer à nos soldats avec précision quel batiments à détruire en premier, se sera un peu la pure anarchie dans les rangs & il vaudra mieux préparer les terrain avec les pouvoirs.
Le jeu est construit par niveaux (8 niveaux + 3 bonus) où il faudra conquérir un autre village gérer par un autre dieu & une fois l'autre village conquit, on passera au suivant... (1/2 à 1 heure par niveau maximum où on attendra la plupart du temps que notre Mana se recharge pour lancer des sorts sur l'autre village)
La reconstruction en cas de destruction étant assez rapide, il faudra bien choisir ses sorts mais le tout restera très simple, l'adversaire ne lançant ses pouvoirs qu'assez rarement, en visant mal & souvent au même endroit...
Graphiquement à peine plus beau que le B&W de 2001...
Sympathique mais forcèment très limité, court, répétitif & avec un gros manque de liberté & de challenge.
Il servira donc plus de piqure de rappel pour faire ou refaires les 2 Black & White qui étaient nettement plus complet & dense rien que dans leur tutoriel!

review:
Tags: Tycoon&Simulator&Sim&City
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Laggy mouse cursor. Low framerates. Terraform oriented godgame with spells. No savegames. Play War for the Overworld or DungeonsIII instead.

First Impression: About 5 missions in and the tutorial messages are getting more advanced and I think nearing the end. Might adjust review after a few full games. 

User interface has issues. Why is there a pillar of light at all times at middle of screen and why does it attract the mouse cursor like a magnet. Why are the messages not easily skippable with a single on screen key like spacebar or enter. Seems instance-based without an ability to save once you start a mission which is okay by me. Game seems quite alright. 

Review: The tutorial messages cannot seemingly be skipped and sometimes require an action to go away require patience and calm to get through. Tutorial itself is very informative. Mana system is intuitive and makes sense as it rewards you for good village management. No obvious needs/psychology or flavor of godhood systems no avatar kaiju furries like in Black & White. Just simple raise and lower terrain, ability to make it rain or control weather and thats about it. ESC key offers a perfect cheat sheet at a glance of all the keybinds. The multiple auto-camera modes on hotkey and on-screen toggle are useful. The job system for your creatures is fairly well thought out and requires some balancing by the player in a way that seems fair. Combat is simple totemplacing + flatten the way + use harmful weather effect on foes if you have anything left. Reminds me a bit of Dungeon Keeper in that sense but without as much corridor clutter and traps to contend with. Even on max settings the game is not all that pretty but it has an art style and at least is clean and pleasant with somewhat adorable little minions.

review:
So, you can beat it in a day, or an afternoon if you're more hardcore than me. You probably won't pick it up again unless you want to try for the steam achievements, or you've got another afternoon to kill to see if you can beat your high scores...soley for the sake of beating your high scores. Some people are into that. I'm probably done with it. 

Thats why I'm recommending it. For <$5 you can buy, finish, and beat a game. No dailies. No weekly event. No life sucking eternal online micro transaction angst. Sometimes thats nice.

However, because its an afternoon jaunt, the entire game felt like the tutorial for something bigger. And maybe it was-because there are bonus missions that I just don't have the stamina to attrition to a win. If I had spent more time or actually needed to learn a "strategy" at any point during the campaign, maybe I would find them to be the challenge, but I find them obnoxious. The whole campaign was "ok, baby step me through how this works, ok cool! I win. I like winning." and then you get to the "you've defeated the greatest evil! but wait...something is lurkiing..." and its instant hard mode/you're the underdog/we made these for the hardcore guy who reviewed the game and said it was too easy and/or childish. 

So yes, its pretty easy (minus the bonus missions) and pretty short, and its also pretty cute and I liked the interface and think this model for "god games" could make its way to tablet or phones pretty easily, and I would buy something similar on those platforms. I wish there were more "god games" out there, that aren't part of the play-to-progress or pay-to-win or login-everyday-till-eternity-and-maybe-you'll-get-somewhere sorts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045655704', 'num_games_owned': 3553, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1488712528}
review:
L'idée est bien, un genre de [i]Populous[/i] version plus légère et plus "mignonne" avec les créatures qui peuplent ce monde...mais c'est loin d'être réussi pour moi.
Dans [i]Idol Hands[/i], on est un Dieu, et avec nos pouvoirs de Dieu nous devons amener nos créatures, persécutées par une autre tribu et un autre Dieu, à anéantir leurs agresseurs pour enfin vivre en paix. Il va donc falloir "développer" la tribu et mettre des bâtons dans les roues de l'autre avec nos pouvoirs.
L'ennui...c'est que concrètement, nous, on ne fait pas grand chose. On indique vite fait à la tribu quoi faire, et on les regarde faire... On ne choisit pas où on place les bâtiments, on dégage juste brièvement le terrain pour que notre créature construise sa maison, pas forcément où c'est le mieux. On ne peut pas séléctionner la ou les créatures voulues, elles vadrouillent à leur guise en faisant leurs tâches. Quand on veut lancer les guerriers à l'attaque, on place un totem dans la zone à attaquer...et si ils ne restent pas bloquer en chemin, ils s'y dirigent et on les regarde galérer. Voir un guerrier perdre 75% de sa vie contre un vulgaire bûcheron ennemi...c'est à se demander si les stats sont différentes entre les différentes fonctions des créatures... Et c'est un peu gênant puisque l'attaque est le seul moyen de terminer le niveau. On n'a pas assez de mana pour tout détruire avec nos pouvoirs et on ne peut tout simplement pas atteindre la pièce centrale ennemie avec. Du coup, ça peut être long...très long...20 minutes pour faire un niveau qui pourrait se boucler en 7, ou carrément 45 minutes parce que les guerriers restent coincés au village, incapables d'emprunter le chemin énorme, évident et on ne peut plus dégagé pour atteindre la base ennemie...ou simplement parce qu'ils veulent tout détruire avant d'attaquer le seul élément qui compte vértiablement...et qu'ils s'y prennent comme des manches.
On peut faire 5 types de créatures, n'ayant chacune qu'une seule utilité (puisqu'on ne peut leur dire quoi faire) : le bûcheron pour récupérer du bois, le fermier pour nourrir les créatures, un autre dont j'ai oublié le nom pour récupérer le fer, le soldat pour attaquer et défendre, et le prêtre pour faire augmenter notre mana plus vite et défendre le village en convertissant les soldats qui nous attaquent. On ne peut "diriger" via le totem que les soldats, ce sont donc les seuls à pouvoir attaquer. On ne peut pas envoyer les prêtres attaquer. Et quand je dis qu'ils "défendent", disons que si un soldat ennemi passe à proximité de sa maison, oui il va le convertir, mais il ne fera pas la moitié du village pour le protéger.
Dieu que nous sommes, nous disposons de plusieurs pouvoirs : on peut égaliser, monter ou creuser le terrain, faire pleuvoir, foudroyer, provoquer un séisme (léger hein...quelques fissures pour détruire deux trois bâtiments max), faire tomber une météorite et créer un volcan. C'est cool. Mais c'est dommage que l'utilité soit limitée. L'ennemi fait pousser un volcan au milieu de notre village et détruit 7-8 bâtiments ! Catastrophe ! On réapplatit le terrain avec juste deux sorts d'égalisation, on recrée en 5 secondes les créatures qui ont pu mourrir à cause du volcan, et elles vont simplement reconstruire ce qui a été détruit à la même place ou presque. Ce qui brûle encore et s'éteindra dans quelques secondes sera rapidement réparé...ouf... L'ennemi fait bien sûr de même si on fait un volcan dans son village, mais lui sera juste plus lent.
Dans le jeu, il y a 4 tutoriels, 8 niveaux normaux, et 3 bonus. C'est peu. Mais avec du recul, vu le temps qu'il faut pour boucler un malheureux niveau...c'est mieux. Il n'y a qu'un seul moyen de gagner, un seul but pour tous les niveaux (hormis les premiers qui apprennent comment jouer). Il y a toujours du fer à côté de nous au début du niveau, l'ennemi ne nous attaque que très peu, et très mal, il n'y a pas de difficulté à "résister" à ses assauts. 
Graphiquement, ce n'est pas moche, mais ce n'est pas génial non plus. Les créatures ne sont vraiment pas terribles elles, du bon vieux polygone, zéro animation du "visage". Musicalement et niveau sonore, rien à reprocher (sauf quand les créatures se bloquent dans du...vide...et crient 3 fois de joie sans raison chaque seconde...).
En bref, sans dire que [i]Idol Hands[/i] est un mauvais jeu, c'est un jeu ennuyant. Il est pauvre en contenu, pauvre graphiquement, pauvre en jouabilité et surtout pauvre en fun. Je me suis bien plus ennuyé qu'amusé sur ce jeu, ce qui motive ma recommandation négative... Si vous voulez quand même lui donner sa chance, attendez que le jeu soit en solde.

review:
First of all, I love Civilization type games and the challenges they bring. I bought this game on sale back in October (2016) and was not too disappointed. In this game, you play a deity that is lovingly worshiped by a small tribe of humanoid creatures that resemble bipedal lemmings. They follow your every command and will build, harvest crops, raise offspring, kill enemies, and even bring you token offerings in exchange for your divine protection.

It's addictive and each level gets progressively harder, introducing new elements to game play. If you're easily frustrated, then this is NOT the game for you.

review:
Idol Hands zählt für mich zu den Spielen, welche ewig lange auf meiner Wunschliste verkommen sind. Viele Reviews raten aus verschiedenen Gründen vom Spiel ab, was auch mich erstmal Abstand nehmen ließ. Jetzt wo ich selber mal anzocken konnte muss ich sagen: Es ist gar nicht mal so schlecht, aber es ist allemal nicht perfekt!

Das meiste was kritisiert wurde ist absolut die Steuerung und auch ich kann da nur zustimmen: Ja, sie ist nicht wirklich PC tauglich! Da hätte man absolut ein klein wenig mehr Arbeit rein stecken können, die Steuerung zu reworken, was absolut kein großes Aufriss gewesen wäre. Auf Dauer kann man sich aber auch an die Steuerung gewöhnen, wenn man lernt WASD zu ignorieren (WASD-Movement locked aktuell die Maus in der Bildmitte, was die WASD-Steuerung in meinen Augen überflüssig und frickelig macht). Insgesamt finde ich persönlich die Steuerung nicht schwerwiegend hinderlich, doch sie ginge allemal besser.

Die Grafik ist insgesamt "ok". Die Models wirken echt süß und kreativ gemacht, aber etwas zu polygonarm (Für Mobile wäre es genau richtig, aber für PC nicht so wirklich). Aber insgesamt ist allemal kein Manko in meinen Augen. Man kann es voll und ganz neutral sehen.

Die Schwierigkeit ist da hingegen ein ganz anderes Problem. Ich meine: Ich bin alles andere als gut in RTS. Aber mit den einfachsten Taktiken, welche einem sehr schnell in den Sinn kommen, lassen sich Gegner ziemlich gut ausbremsen und überrennen. Ich habe das Spiel zwar noch nicht komplett durch, jedoch wirkt das Schwierigkeitsgrad bisher wie "Leicht" wenn nicht sogar "Sehr Leicht". Die KI ist dabei gar nicht mal so schlecht, jedoch findet auch sie irgendwo ihre Grenzen. (Edit: Es hat sich nicht viel daran getan. Im letzten richtigen Match macht zwar die KI mal etwas mehr Druck, aber der Spieler ist bis dahin so eingespielt, so dass es immer noch "Leicht" ist).

Auch einige wenige Bugs sind selbst jetzt noch zu finden (Patchs scheint es keine mehr zu geben soweit ich es beurteilen kann über Steam). So kann es passieren das die Eisen-Sammler kein Eisen sammeln, wenn man nicht das Eisenvorkommen erst in den Boden einsenkt und dann die Fläche begradigt, sondern direkt die Fläche begradigt. Auch sind bei mir Dorfbewohner random irgendwo auf der Map gespawnt, wo ich mir nicht vorstellen kann, dass das gewollt ist.

Insgesamt lässt sich also sagen: Da müsste eigentlich noch gut 1 Monat Arbeit und Polishing mal her um das Game ordentlich zu machen, doch das wird niemals passieren nehme ich an. Dennoch gebe ich einen Daumen hoch, aus einem ganz einfachen Grund: Das Spiel hat trotz seiner Vielzahl an Macken echt Spaß gemacht und war selbst mit kleineren Buggs absolut spielbar! :)

Für den Salepreis (1,24€) kann ich allemal eine Kaufempfehlung an alle aussprechen, welche sich nicht so leicht kleinkriegen lassen von dem oben genannten. Alle anderen sollten das Spiel vielleicht meiden.
Für den Normalpreiss (aktuell 4,99€ nur noch) kann ich es nur an jene weiter empfehlen, welche noch nie mit dem Genre zu tun gehabt haben (und es interessant finden) und sich von dem oben genannten ebenfalls nicht einschüchtern lassen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043428953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1471796363}
review:
Positives: Easy to learn game! I figured out how to do everything even before the tutorial was completed. Very simple graphics, so it runned great on my old laptop (Which is 5 years old.) It's kid friendly, and I was not sure wether I was playing a childrens game, or a adult game. I'd say it's perfect for kids. It has some great charm, and the kind sensation the game gives a impression off, feels really good! It lightened my mood. Cool graphics when lowering land!

Negatives: I couldn't descide what buildings to build, and where to place them. The Furlings did that for me. I really disliked that. There was no way to make roads, and more fancy looking towns. There was no structure, or streets, walls for protection etc. Just a town, and all I could do as a "God" was to create land. And I could do some natural powers, such as rain, lightning, vulcano, etc. But those got old, pretty fast, because of the graphics when shooting one off. Annoying to see it come up in a circle every single time, and being locked to it... And making a pathway from one hight level to the other was hard, seeing as how when I just lower ground it is in the shape of a hand, while highening lang was more "correct" in my head, as it highed only a nice radius around my cursor. The game only had 8 levels, and 3 bonus levels. The last bonus level was dissapointing, even though I get why it was as it was. But the game story in general was very dissapointing. I had hoped for a bigger challenge, and a longer story. It seemed to me, as if the developers gave up on it. 

I'm sorry, but I would not reccomend buying this game.

review:
[h1]So disappointing seeing what could have been a truly awesome game being botched like this. It could have been great![/h1]

For me, this game instantly presented problems:

[h1]Major issues:[/h1]

- It immensely increased in fps lagging [i]very[/i] quickly as the village expanded even just a tiny bit. It seemed like it would drop down 2-5 in FPS-rate for each border expansion or flattening of land, [i]getting just worse and worse, for no obvious reason whatsoever.[/i]

Neither the (low) amounts of units, the decent-enough graphics, or even somehow any added complexity to the map during play, seems as reasonable explanation for the game to perform in this manner.

After flattening the land 4-6 times around the first non-tutorial village, the constantly decreasing [b](and never recovering)[/b] FPS of the game became unbearable. (And changing graphics quality made no noticable difference.)

[h1]Minor issues:[/h1]

- Instead of simply being able to click on the ground with the pointer (like in B&W), the point-of-effect was controlled by WSAD keys, shown by a continuous beam on the ground; Making even having a hand/pointer feel pretty much useless. It would have been much better if there was simply a key to be pressed to decouple the hand into UI clicking.

- No matter what i tried, it seemed like there was no way to hasten or skip the messages of the Furling mentor-guy. I just has to wait for the message boxes to disappear, one after the other, even if it was just one very short line of text.


[i]I bought this game because Black & White, Settlers, From Dust and Mega Lo Mania are all at the top of list of my favorite games ever. But the price made me suspicious, and the game sadly confirmed my reason for suspicion.[/i]

[b]I have put the game on "Follow", hoping to some day see it in better shape and to buy it again then. But this time it felt like i paid (a small amount of money) for a demo of a going-to-be-awesome game. :([/b]

review:
[h1]Populous? Eher nicht.	[/h1]

Ich hab mir das Spiel für 5 Cent auf Green Man Gaming gekauft und habe daher wirklich nicht viel erwartet. Zunächst war ich von dem "niedlichem" Artstyle geblendet, bis ich bemerkt habe, wie häßlich die Graphik tatsächlich ist. 
Egal, wen interessiert das Aussehen, wenn die inneren Werte stimmen?

Wie in Populous kann man nur indirekt, mittels Terreforming, Einfluss auf seine Bevölkerung nehmen, dazu kommt ein rudimentäres Ressourcenmanagement. Je größer die Bevölkerung, desto mehr Mana, desto mehr flaches Land, desto mehr Bauern, desto mehr Bevölkerung. Jedem Viech (so hab ich meine Bevölkerung nach 10 Minuten genannt) kann man eine Klasse zuweisen, wobei sich nicht erschließen lässt wie Ressourcen tatsächlich genutzt werden.

Maussteuerung gibts nur sehr eingeschränkt, sobald man WASD benutzt (wozu man im Tutorial animiert wird) wird der Cursor zentral platziert. Tasten sind nicht frei belegbar, Kamera nicht frei drehbar, KI ist strohdumm und Terraforming total nutzlos, das Spiel ist eigentlich nicht den Aufwand dieses Textes wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072372214', 'num_games_owned': 1764, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1478063770}
review:
[i]Please read completely before making full judgment. The TL;DR is at the bottom.[/i]

Before I purchased this game, I saw that the top reviews were negative ones. However, I liked the screenshots and description, and I am fairly open-minded with low expectations, so I figured I'd give it a shot. I think one of the biggest problems is that people are going into this expecting more than what it is. The popular tags really should include "Casual".

Overall, I liked it. It is a God game, but on a Casual scale. It does not reach the grandiosity of many other God games. I can understand how there are so many negative reviews, especially the ones made on release day at a higher price point. Considering Pocket Games planned to, and did release, an iOS version after PC, I think the design was targeting mobile from the beginning. This game is limited in scope, scale, depth, etc. I will go into it more later.

I have played the game to full completion, including all achievements. It took around 5 hours to complete, and then another 5 or so to grind the "Tree Expert" achievement. So, it is a short game. Does that make it bad? Not really. I like being able to complete games. It's perfect for people like me that don't have much free time due to work and family. I completed it over 3 nights.

[h1]My Detailed Opinions[/h1]

The characters have a unique design to them. They are charming, but they are also fun to set on fire or strike down with lightning. They make noises and exclamations, but it's nothing complex.

The terrain design is well done. There aren't a large number of textures, but they fit the overall feel. The islands themselves include little scenic bits that might go unnoticed, such as a variety of flowers, ferns and other undergrowth. Being able to alter it is also nice. It's not as detailed of alterations as something like From Dust, which I played on Xbox 360, but it's still there.

The game is not that difficult. Due to the limited size of the playing field, there is only so much that can be done. During the campaign, there are caps on the number of each type of Furling other than Warrior. Only the sandbox allows more.

Each campaign "level" is just a variation of another. Since there are only 5 types of Furlings and just a handful of God powers, the only thing that makes each different is the island configuration, starting buildings on each side, and so forth. Also, I swear the AI starts cheating more. On the final level, it was like the end of days for my side. I was spending quite a bit of time putting out fires, fixing the terrain and creating replacement Furlings. I don't see how the AI was able to throw so many meteors when I had the same number of Priests and couldn't do the same.

The controls take some getting used to. However, once you've used them a few times, it's not so bad. Also, some of the things mentioned in older reviews have been addressed. Check out the discussions to see what the developer has said.

The key features are very deceptive. Here's a breakdown:
[list]
[*][i]Play God...[/i] : It sounds like they can be commanded. They can't. The description counters with "your people will live their own lives". Even the Warriors go all willy nilly when they get near the enemy. In almost all war strategy games I've played, if I put a target, my troops go after it. These guys use the Totem as more of a compass marker than a destination.
[*][i]Shape a beautiful...[/i] : Yes, I like the land. But, calling it a "world" makes it sound massive. So does the "take over the world" wording in the main description. In reality, each mission is a relatively small island or pair of islands (enemy on one side, you on the other). The only way to make it any bigger is to keep leveling it out into the water. But in no way is it global domination like it sounds.
[*][i]Feel the power...[/i] : Sorry, it's not "massive" natural disasters. They are fairly weak. Even the volcanoes can be countered. They are short-lived and have a short projectile range. Just flatten them and use Rain. Anything destroyed can be quickly rebuilt. Earthquake can only take out buildings in a close range. It's not as destructive as a real one. A well-targeted meteor [i]might[/i] take out a building and set some on fire, but it doesn't cause a massive crater or such.
[*][i]Play the game...[/i] : There really isn't multiple strategies other than mixing up which disasters you use and when/where Warriors are sent. But, with the limited scope, there isn't any real replayability like bigger RTS games.
[/list]

In the description, it says this:

[quote]learn skills to eventually forming an immense fighting force that you can unleash upon your enemy’s population to wipe them out[/quote]

They don't learn anything as they are just created as one of 5 types (and only 1 is a fighter), "immense" is not an appropriate term for a standing army of 10-20 warriors, and the enemy's population is just as limited as yours. Wiping them out isn't that difficult.

[h1]The Quick Review[/h1]

+ Pleasant, but not overly done, graphics
+ Terrain design and control
+ Charming characters
+ Not too difficult, not too long (it's [i]Casual[/i])

~ The Furlings sometimes set up shop in strange places. Even when there is room near a resource, they sometimes build too far away.
~ Caps on the types of Furlings during campaign.
~ AI that seems to cheat.

- That stupid "Tree Expert" achievement. It's so out of place compared to the others. It's so annoying that I made a guide for it.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=658881594
- Even with a GPU that exceeds the "Recommended" (higher end) requirement, I had to leave it on the medium setting to run smoothly.
- Game gets laggy on sandbox once there are a lot of Furlings and trees. Loading my Tree Expert save would even cause it to go Not Responding for a while.

[h1]Final Say[/h1]

Even with the questionable and negative points, I still liked it, and I do recommend it for the Casual audience that wants something a little more than an Alawar strategy game. If you are looking for a world-scale God game with plenty of complexity, turn back now! The price is questionable. If Casual is your primary thing, then $4.99, about $1/hr, isn't too bad. I got it on sale for $1.24, and I [i]highly[/i] recommend it at that price.

review: Idol Hands currently isn't perfect by any stretch of the imagination, but it's fun and enjoyable. I'm aware the devs are active on the steam forums and are planning (during March 2015 - less than a month after release), a path to fix some issues people have reported (some being feature requests). To me, it already looks good and has great potential. Idol Hands is a God-like game where- belief auto-collects, you can raise/lower AND smooth land, you can set earthquakes, rain clouds and lighting bolts, there are 5 "professions" you can set your followers (woodcutter, farmer, blacksmith, priest, warrior) who will help gather resources to kill the opposition, there are (IIRC a quote) about 11 "worlds" each consisting of multiple (smallish) levels (you can only have 10 of each profession except warrior which has 20 IIRC). Game has story line/tutorial, is "complete" and is undergoing quite a bit of work (looking at forum threads), graphics are medium quality (some things like earthquakes and raising/lowering land do look a little "janky").

author: {'steamid': '76561197974879421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1424326649}
review:
This game was fairly interesting at first.  As the tutorial walks you through your new powers, I was feeling like this would have a fun level of complexity to it.  
However, the game quickly becomes repetative and tedious with the end game of each level taking an inordinately long time to finish.  
The game strategy is basically choosing what order to build your 5 types of units in, most with a hard cap on the total amount you can have, and managing when to use your mana, as in using a cheap power now, or saving for a more powerful attack.  You have no control over the placement of your buildings or actions of your workers and very limited control over your soldiers.
The game is also fairly short, I beat it in about 5 hours, maybe less.  About a third of this time was spent more or less just waiting for my soldiers to finish taking out the enemy's town with virtually no resistance.
There is a sandbox mode once you are finished, but other than using my earthmoving powers to draw a few funny shapes into the dirt, it got boring very quickly.
This is not a bad game, but I would not recommend buying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961138963', 'num_games_owned': 1138, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1424372297}
review:
The short and skinny...

[b]PROS[/b]

[olist]
[*]Decent graphics, but that's subjective.
[*]Devs are active in the forums.
[*]Devs said in a post they plan on adding more content/features. Some may be game enhancements (camera, zoom, speed settings), but extra content such as new lands and spells will most likely be DLC. So this is more of a "nuetral" variable, not necessarily a "pro."
[/olist]


[b]CONS[/b]

[olist]
[*]limited "God actions."  You can raise, lower, flatten land. You can call in a few powers such as earthquake, lightening, meteor, etc. But that's about it. These powers don't seem all that powerful in game. Easy mode = build up decent population with 5 priests, spam earthquake in enemy village (you can destroy 2-3 each time). It's the only strategy needed to beat the AI it seems.
[*]5 classes (farmer, woodcutter, miner, warrior, priest).  And you have no control over them w/ the exception of a totem you put down for the warrior. No upgrades or enhancements, no strategic planning or placement.
[*]You dion't decide where to build. You create a minion, and they take over from there. You have NO part in their life after creation.
[*]Limited camera control - either sky high overview, or on above ground. No in between zoom or close ups.
[*]Battles seem so underwhelming. There is a heart icon over minions that represent their health, but the battles seem rather long (no way to increase damage. And attacking the villages? Get the snacks and driniks...you'll be there for a while. There's no health meter over any building so you have no idea how damaged the building is. Destroying villages, even if you have an overwhelming army just takes forever.
[*]No game speed options...which due to the above is really, really bad. You play at normal speed only. This game BEGS for a speed increase for the long battles and traveling and building times.
[*]The campaign is really just a tutorial. Having a tutorial is a good thing, but to have it BE the campagin is questionable IMO.
[*]Once you create a minion (Furling) you cannot destroy him or train him to be something else. So if you create a lot of woodcutters in the beginning but don't need them later...you are stuck with them. As I said, once you create your minions that's it...you have no control over them afterwards.
[*]AI is very, very bad IMO.  The enemy god will do silly things while his village is being attacked, such as water farms or continue to send his soldiers to my village while I have 2:1 or 3:1 ratio of warriors attacking his own + using powers to destroy his buildings.  In addition, my own, uncontrollable warriors just attack things randomly. Instead of attacking the enemy base, they will attack things that aren't relevant, such as the standby enemy minions who aren't assigned to any task. 
[/olist]

I don't feel like God with this game in its current state. It's extremely limited in what can be done. Your playstyle and options are extremely limited. This is a very, very casual game. It lacks what almost every other rts or previous God game has in terms of variety, actions, features, etc.

If you are expecting depth and strategy, lots of things to do, you'll be disappointed. If you are expecting just a simple, casual, easy game to play to pass the time, you'll have fun with it.

I highly recommend watching let's play videos before purchasing.  I don't see the value of the game w/ the current asking price. Compared to other indie games on Steam, this seems more like a $10 game, at best for what you get out of it.

You will finish campaign in less than 3 hours. There just isn't much to do in the game.  There's no variety. It feels like it is still early access w/ such a lack of content. It's like they tried to compensate for the lack of content by creating a tutorial/campaign. I'd much rather have a shorter campaign and have more stuff to do. 

RECOMMENDATION

Hold off for now and see how the game develops. It has potential, but hasn't reached it yet and it there just isn't any way of telling if it ever well atm.

review:
まだチュートリアルを少し進めた程度のレビューです。
まず、ウインドウモードで起動が出来ません。私は英語が出来ないので、ウインドウモードでチュートリアルを翻訳しながら進めようと思ってたので残念。ＳＴＥＡＭの起動設定編集をしてもフルスクリーンで起動してしまいます。
しかたないのでとりあえずチュートリアルは読まずに進めました。

次に操作性が最悪最低です。ＷＡＳＤは使えないし、カメラ移動も上手くいかない。カメラを寄せたり引いたりも出来ない。
地面を凹ませたり盛上がらせたり、雨や雷を降らせたり出来るキーがＰとかＬとかＮです。意味わかんない。

敵ＮＰＣ村と、村の発展を競いながら相手を根絶やしにするのが目的のゲームです。
不細工な村人を可愛がりながら村を好きなようにノンビリ作っていくゲームだと思っていたらちょっと注意したほうがいいかもしれません。
あと、私のようにチュートリアルを読んでなかったり、理解しないまま進めて、分からなくなったら後でちゃんと読もうとは考えないことです。
もう１度チュートリアルを見るには最初のステージからやり直さないといけないし、それまで進めてきたステージも無かったことにされます。
操作性とか色々改善されたとしても、２０ドルの価値はなさそうです。

camera control, you have none really.  No rotation, no zoom/unzoom, just overhead and action. another reviewer says the right mouse button rotates, tried it, it didnt work for me.
Length, its short, and a good portion of the game is spent in the tutorial that you cannot bypass
its just not grand.  you get 50 population, with that you have to figure out how to divide them into 5 catagories.
no way to speed up the action
you start with a set score and it counts down when you start, no way to recoup the score ( so far the only reason to replay, to beat the score)

Bottom line:

I miss watching your monster change according to his actions, i miss the way LionHead made you feel playing  B&W, its scope, the ability to help your villages, the good/evil dynamic.  This is what made B&W great, what made it epic.  Idol hands cant deliver on that premise, maybe with a well tuned expansion it can, but now...no.  After the hype at GMG i felt they were trying to make promises they failed to deliver on.  As the 1st venture for Greenman loaded, they need to learn that people will only pay for a short, flawed game if the story and the game dynamics pick up the slack.  IH doesnt get there at its current cost.  It is fun, it is simple to learn, and if they continue to develope the game, it can be what its trying to be, so i recommend it for a sale or a coupon purchase as a casual game.

7/10
kids 5+

UPDATE: I can easily recommend the game now, as they fixed a lot of the issues I had a year ago.  It's also only $5 as opposed to $20.  Changing my review from negative to positive.

---

Feb 2015

Oh, how I wanted to recommend it.  On the plus side, it’s a god game that lets you reshape the land so that your furlings can construct their own structures as well as cast powers like earthquakes and volcanoes (similar to Populous).  On the surface, this sounds great!  On the other, there are some really odd things about this game that make me scratch my head in wonder as to what the developers were thinking.  There are no time controls, no WASD or arrow key camera movement, no zooming (there is a fixed bird’s eye view), holding in right mouse click and moving the mouse up and down (not left or right oddly) rotates the camera, no HP bars above buildings, your score decreases as you play (rushing you into beating it more quickly), and more.  As far as I can tell, there are eight levels on the campaign menu and no skirmish modes.  The inclusion of the latter would have given the game some replay value and could have made it worth $20 despite these short-sided gameplay mechanics.  As it stands, it just doesn't do enough to justify that price tag (in my opinion).

Quick Impressions: Idol Hands is a God Game that features terrain deformation as a requirement for growing your village of Furlings as well as being used offensively/defensively (whichever way works best strategically) against the opposing God/village.

Easily the Terrain Deformation is the stand-out feature in this game and is handled remarkably well and is graphically impressive. You'll need to use these powers to level land so that you're farmers can cultivate crops and feed your population so that you can produce more workers (wood/metal/priests) and warriors to protect your village. As you level the land around you, the border of your colony will slowly grow larger as your workers build new buildings automatically.

Another plus that I really enjoyed but doesn't really change much of the game was clicking on the minimap and zooming out super far and you are presented with a landscape that is very reminiscent of the view enjoyed in Act Raiser. Again, not the biggest thing but I really liked it.

The big negatives that I have for the game is the SUPER long mandatory tutorial sections (1+ hour(s)) and the inability to speed up the game. Everything in the game runs at 1x speed, always. So the early part of the game is rather boring because you don't even have all of your spells yet.

Overall though, the game is very charming and family friendly.

Recommended
